results.title: An Essay on war
results.creator_credit: Andrew A Rooney and Essay Productions
results.brief_description: Examines past and present reasons for waging war, the distance between those who declare war and those who fight it, the self-seeking of peacetime and the high productivity and united attitude of wartime, and the great ideals of war beside its horrible reality. Presents the positive and negative side of many moral questions related to war, and queries the need of civilised people to kill one another.
results.description: Examines past and present reasons for waging war, the distance between those who declare war and those who fight it, the self-seeking of peacetime and the high productivity and united attitude of wartime, and the great ideals of war beside its horrible reality. Presents the positive and negative side of many moral questions related to war, and queries the need of civilised people to kill one another.

results.title: The Esperance story
results.creator_credit: Michael Thornhill, Richard Mason, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Western Australia. Dept. of Native Welfare
results.brief_description: Esperance, a small town on the southern coast of Western Australia, is a community centre for wealthy pastoralists and graziers. A smaller number of First Nations people also live thereunder the control of the Western Australian Department of Native Welfare. The establishment of some First Nations farming businesses is an economic opportunity but also a challenge to the town’s culture.

results.title: Eskimo hunters
results.creator_credit: W. Kay Norton and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Describes the life of the Eskimos of north-western Alaska, 25,000 of whom live in scattered villages in a region in which the winters are six months long.

results.title: Eskimo children
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: A study of an Eskimo family living on Nunivak Island, off the Alaskan coast, showing how the Eskimo people solve the problem of providing food, clothing, shelter, and transport for themselves. Today the results of the contacts made with the outside world can be seen in the changing customs of the Eskimo people.

results.title: Escape to nowhere
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Surveys the general problem of drug abuse in Australia, pointing out the extent of dependence on alcohol, tobacco and various pharmaceutical preparations and the damage resulting from them as well as the use of illegal narcotics and hallucinogens

results.title: Know your foods
results.creator_credit: Stanley Moore and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Science”.
Stresses the part food plays in the development of the human body. Illustrating with varius food types, the film explains the meaning of such terms as calories, proteins and vitamins and how to obtain sufficient of these for correct diet. The film concludes with five simple rules for healthy living.

results.title: Escape from sanity: a study of schizophrenia
results.brief_description: A detailed investigation of schizophrenia, the most common form of mental illness, interviewing patients and staff of a psychiatric hospital. Considers the causes of the condition and approaches to treatment and stresses the modern approach - the confrontation situation - based on research in schizophrenics’ families.

results.title: Errigal
results.creator_credit: Patrick Carey, Vivien Carey and Aengus Films
results.brief_description: Errigal is the highest peak of the Decryveagh Mountains in Donegal, Ireland. The mountains and weather impose their own moods on the landscape and the film conveys this feeling of personality in a landscape through the striking use of visuals, music and natural sound
